message_1: What is the likelihood of a top quark pair production in proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider, and how can this be used to study the properties of the top quark?
message_2:
The likelihood of top quark pair production in proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) depends on the center-of-mass energy of the collisions and the luminosity of the LHC. At the LHC, the center-of-mass energy is currently 13 TeV, and the integrated luminosity achieved in 2018 was about 60 inverse femtobarns.

The cross-section for top quark pair production at 13 TeV is approximately 800 picobarns. The likelihood of producing a top quark pair in a single proton-proton collision can be calculated by multiplying the cross-section by the instantaneous luminosity. However, it is more common to discuss the number of top quark pairs produced over a certain period, which can be calculated by multiplying the cross-section by the integrated luminosity. Using the 2018 integrated luminosity of 60 inverse femtobarns, we can estimate that about 48,000 top quark pairs were produced during that year.

Studying top quark pair production at the LHC is essential for understanding the properties of the top quark, which is the heaviest known elementary particle. By analyzing the decay products of top quark pairs, physicists can measure various properties of the top quark, such as its mass, electric charge, and couplings to other particles. Additionally, the production and decay of top quarks can be sensitive to physics beyond the Standard Model, making top quark pair production an important probe for new physics.
